tool.name: Full_Indicator_Tool

param.name: in_poly
param.dialogReference: The area of the restoration site being assessed. All other input datasets will be re-projected based on the projection used for the restoration sites. All fields and spatial data in this feature layer will be copied from the sites to the output table. The output table from one partial analysis can be used as input to the next.

param.name: in_pnts
param.dialogReference: People in the area around the restoration sites that could potentially receive benefits from site restoration. A buffer of 12 miles around the site will usually be enough, though the range may vary depending on the benefits chosen for assessment. Points representing individual homes should be entered here (suggested source: E-911 address data). If a grid (raster) representation of population is being used, enter this dataset as "Population Raster" below.

param.name: popRast
param.dialogReference: Most benefits require a dataset representing people in the area around the restoration sites that could potentially receive benefits from site restoration. The spatial range where people should be considered varies depending on the benefits chosen for assessment, but a buffer of 12 miles around the site will usually be enough. A grid format (raster) representation of population should be entered here. If vector point representations of individual homes are being used, instead enter the dataset as "Address points" above. Suggested sources include EPA's EnviroAtlas Dasymetric population.

param.name: flood
param.dialogReference: Flood risk reduction benefits flow from where they are produced to downstream areas that would otherwise flood.

param.name: view
param.dialogReference: Scenic view benefits flow from aesthetically pleasing landscapes outward to surrounding areas.

param.name: edu
param.dialogReference: Environmental education benefits are the only ones that can be assessed without a population dataset (addresses or population raster).

param.name: rec
param.dialogReference: Recreation benefits require people to travel to the site where recreation opportunities are to benefit.

param.name: bird
param.dialogReference: Bird watching benefits flow from where birds are located outward to surrounding areas where people can see them.

param.name: socEq
param.dialogReference: The social equity of restoration sites can be compared for each benefit based on who is expected to benefit, but these will typically be similar across different benefits so it is recommended that users run social equity once for each site.

param.name: rel
param.dialogReference: A restoration site that will persist further into the future is rated as higher priority than a comparable site that is not expected to persist into the future.

param.name: flood_zone
param.dialogReference: Dataset that defines flood zones (e.g. 100-yr or 500-yr) where flooding occurs. Suggested sources include FEMA or NOAA.

param.name: flood_sub
param.dialogReference: Point, line or polygon dataset defining flood prevention infrastructure. Suggested sources include USGS's NHD+ dataset, or FEMA.

param.name: edu_inst
param.dialogReference: Point dataset that defines education institutions that may receive benefits. Suggested sources include state or local departments of education.

param.name: bus_stp
param.dialogReference: Point, line or polygon dataset that defines bus stops that help people access benefits. Suggested sources include State department of transportation or other public transit authorities.

param.name: trails
param.dialogReference: Point, line or polygon dataset that defines trails that help people access benefits. Suggested sources include NPS, State agencies, and NGOs.

param.name: roads
param.dialogReference: Point, line or polygon dataset that defines other places people may receive benefits. Suggested sources include Tiger, ESRI, Google, E911.

param.name: in_wet
param.dialogReference: Vector dataset that defines existing wetlands. The suggested source is the FWS National Wetlands Inventory (NWI).

param.name: land_use
param.dialogReference: Vector dataset that defines alternative greenspace that may add value. Suggested sources include state agencies, NOAA, or National Land Cover Database (NLCD).

param.name: LULCFld
param.dialogReference: Field identifying greenspace landuse in Landuse/Greenspace (Polygons).

param.name: grn_field_val
param.dialogReference: Values in the above field which are greenspace.

param.name: soc_vul_poly
param.dialogReference: Dataset that defines the social vulnerability of different areas. Suggested sources include NOAA, Social Vulnerability Index.

param.name: soc_field
param.dialogReference: Field in Social Vulnerability dataset designating population vulnerability.

param.name: soc_field_val
param.dialogReference: Values in the field which are vulnerable.

param.name: cons_poly
param.dialogReference: Vector dataset defining areas to be conserved or otherwise protected against future threats and development. Suggested sources include state planning organizations.

param.name: Conservation_Field
param.dialogReference: Field in conservation lands dataset designating protected areas.

param.name: Conservation_Type
param.dialogReference: Values in the above field which are protected.

param.name: outTable
param.dialogReference: A file name and location must be specified for the dataset that results from the analysis. It is recommended that users create a new file geodatabase and save their output there because the folder location of the output file is also used to save intermediate files. If files with the same names as the intermediates already exist in the specified location, they will be deleted and overwritten.

param.name: outReport
param.dialogReference: In addition to the output table, the tool can also create a pdf report when a new PDF Report file name is entered. This requires a .mxd with the report layout be available in the same directory as the file for this tool.

tool.summary: Many of the steps of the RBI spatial analysis process require the same dataset inputs. The Full Tier 1 Assessment tool allows a user to input these datasets once and reuse them for multiple benefits/steps. See the “Data Requirements” manual section for details on all of the datasets used to run the RBI Spatial Analysis Tools and which benefit uses each.
tool.usage: Calculate values for benefit indicators using two or more wetland restoration site polygons and a variety of other input data.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Many of the steps of the RBI spatial analysis process require the same dataset inputs. The Full Tier 1 Assessment tool allows a user to input these datasets once and reuse them for multiple benefits/steps. See the “Data Requirements” manual section for details on all of the datasets used to run the RBI Spatial Analysis Tools and which benefit uses each.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: Justin Bousquin, Michael Charpentier (Report generation), Marc Weber and Tad Larsen (StreamCat)

searchKeys.keyword: Full Assessment; RBI; Rapid Benefit Indicators; Ecosystem Services
